tn.text: In this chapter, Yahweh speaks to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: sit in the dust, virgin daughter of Babylon; sit on the ground ... daughter of the Chaldeans.
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Sitting in the dust was a sign of humiliation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: virgin daughter of Babylon ... daughter of the Chaldeans
tn.text: Both of these phrases refer to the city, Babylon, which is spoken of as if it were a daughter. That the city is a "daughter" indicates how people think fondly of her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "throne" refers to the power to rule. AT: "without the power to rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You will no longer be called dainty and delicate
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "People will no longer call you dainty and delicate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These two words share similar meanings. They describe one who is beautiful and lives in luxury. AT: "very beautiful" or "very luxurious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
a large stone used to grind grain
Yahweh continues to speak to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "You will be naked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Here the word "shame" is a euphemism for one's private parts. This can be translated in active form. AT: "people will see your shame" or "people will see your private parts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Our" refers to Isaiah and the people of Israel. See how you translated "Redeemer" in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:14|41:14]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Translate this phrase in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:01:24|1:24]].
Translate this phrase in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:05:15|5:16]].

This phrase refers to the city, Babylon, which is spoken of as if it were a daughter. That the city is a "daughter" indicates how the Chaldeans think fondly of her. Translate this phrase in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:01|47:1]].

tn.ref: for you will no longer be called
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "for people will no longer call you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Yahweh speaks of Babylon being the capital city of the Babylonian empire as if it were a queen who ruled many kingdoms. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues to speak to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here "I" refers to Yahweh.

Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel being his special possession as if they were his heritage or inheritance. AT: "I defiled my people, who are my special possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: gave them over into your hand
tn.text: Here the word "hand" represents Babylon's power or control. AT: "I put them under your power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you placed a very heavy yoke on the old people
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of the Babylonians oppressing the old people as if they had treated the old people like cattle and put heavy yokes on their necks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will rule forever as sovereign queen
tn.text: Babylon speaks of permanently ruling over many nations as if she were a queen who would rule forever. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You did not take these things to heart
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of thinking carefully about something as if it were placing that thing on one's heart. AT: "You did not consider these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues to speak to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"you luxurious one." This refers to the many luxuries that Babylon enjoyed.
This refers to Babylon's false sense of security in thinking that she will never lose her position of wealth and honor. AT: "who think you are safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I will never sit as a widow ... loss of children
tn.text: Babylon believing that other nations will never be able to conquer her is spoken of as if she will never become a widow or never have children die. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will never sit as a widow
tn.text: "I will never become a widow"

tn.ref: in a moment in one day
tn.text: "suddenly at the same time"
Yahweh continues to speak to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here the word "heart" refers to the inner person. AT: "you say to yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh speaks of disaster as if it were a person who captures Babylon. AT: "You will experience disaster" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Yahweh speaks Babylon being destroyed as if destruction were an object that falls upon the city. AT: "You will experience destruction" or "Others will destroy you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh speaks of Babylon experiencing calamity as if calamity were a person who strikes Babylon. AT: "You will experience calamity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues to speak to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Persist in casting your spells ... perhaps you will scare away disaster
tn.text: Yahweh mocks Babylon by telling her to continue to practice her sorcery to keep bad things away, but he knows that it will not help her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
Yahweh continues to speak to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: they will become like stubble. The fire will burn them up
tn.text: Yahweh compares the magicians and sorcerers to straw that burns quickly in a fire. This means that Yahweh will destroy them as easily as fire burns stubble, and so they are powerless to save Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here the word "hand" represents strength. AT: "the power of the flame" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: There are no coals to warm them and no fire for them to sit by
tn.text: Yahweh emphasizes that this is a destructive fire by stating that it is not one that people will use to warm themselves.
